reviewText:
I've only played a few runs so far, so I haven't unlocked everything yet.
Pros:

+ great pixel-art
+ challenging enemies
+ different way of fighting ( You attack the nearest enemy automaticly and need to dogde the bullets)
+ many unlocks [Items, weapons, books, etc.]
+ many characters to unlock (Each of them plays differently)
+ many different enemies
+ many different bosses to fight
+different areas to explore. (You'll always need to fight through 4 stages with 3 levels + boss level     each)
+ bosses are fair and have unique patterns.
+ champion-enemies with different attacks
+ lovecraftian (might be a con for someone, but I love it)
+ great atmosphere
+ unlocks add new gameplay-mechanics [to example: giant chests, where you need to kill monsters before they open up, which bring massive loot]
+ Rogue-like (perma-death, random levels, etc)
+ customizable key-bindings


Cons:

-Nothing so far.

For 15€, you can't do anything wrong here.

reviewText:
I like this game a lot!

Things start out kinda simple but you unlock new stuff by playing and it gets crazy after a while. It definitely has that just one more run" thing going on. It'll keep you up late.

All the playable characters are my favorite part of the game. They all play VERY differently from each other and it adds a lot.

Hardmode (called Desecration) seems impossible to me... so that's either a pro or a con depending on how good you are at shooters. It gets hard as hell if that's you're thing.

Overall if you're an ARPG / Shooter / Roguelike fan this is a winner. Recommended!"

reviewText:
Deathstate is very interesting sort of game, if you're a fan of roguelight games like binding of isaac you'll likely enjoy this game.  I'll be updating this review as I accumulate times but here are some first thoughts

Pro's/Con's
+Smooth gameplay (I have a fairly decent machine but i have had 0 frame drops while playing it, streaming and watching another stream at the same time)
+dynamic runs (think binding of isaac where every run feels slightly different)
+Diverse Characters (all but 2 of the characters feel very different and have different builds that lend to the characters starting stats and default ability)
+Controller support (they improved the controller functionality a fair amount in the most recent patch)
+Difficult Gameplay (game scales well and has difficult conent, desecration 3 is stupidly hard and it took me about 25 hours of actual gameplay to get my first clear with a stupidly lucky run)
-Dashing seems a bit strange and disadvantagous for controller (would be nice if there was a dash button that would just dash the direction you're facing)
-Limited end act  bosses (NEW BOSSES HAVE BEEN ADDED!)
-Mana/manaregen stat's seem incredibly underwhelming for how many items have them (max mana occasionally is important on expensive mana items due to -mana items leaving you with not enough to cast the spells)
-Level balance seems slightly off (world 3 is a good bit easier than world 4 and I personally think world 2 is more difficult than 4 as well but that's probably just personal bias)


In my opinion this game is definitly worth buying and if the developers keep up with it I could see easily sinking 100+ hours into it.

reviewText:
I got this game as a gift and was immediately intrigued because I've never heard of it.  My first time running it I thought it was very lousy and aesthetically unappealing, but something about it kept me pushing on.   I'd pick it up and play about 15 minutes at a time here and there.  Now I have grown to really enjoy this game and I find myself jumping in almost daily.

You land in a monster inhabited map and your goal is to collect items and find the teleporting exit.  Do this three times without dying and you will face a boss before you can proceed to the next area.  I don't know what is going to happen after a while because I keep dying.  :)  I do know that aiming and shooting is automatic, which works pretty well, so you can focus on dodging projectiles and picking up loot.  It plays better than that sounds.

It's difficult, but fun, with many useful characters and power-ups that can be unlocked to aid you on your runs.  After learning to go after one Elite mob and chests, to get organs per level, I am getting better and farther just about each run.  Maybe I'll even beat it one of these days.

reviewText:
Deathstate is a lot more fun than I first anticipated.  Having seen a lot of footage and information beforehand, I didn't see myself playing it for more than an hour.  Once I started playing yesterday though, I couldn't put it down.

I'm going to do something unorthodox and break down the game based on its own description.  Deathstate is a...

1) Single-stick shooter - this means that you use your controls to move, and the game aims and shoots for you.  My first thought was that this would be annoying, but it's actually quite a positive thing.  You target and fire at the closest enemy, which leaves you with the remaining responsibility to dodge and use items.  And you'll need all the concentration you can get for those two things, especially later in the game when it gets hard.  On top of this you still feel in control because the movement is so fluid and responsive.

2) Roguelike - There is permadeath.  Game runs are quick and brutal when you first play.  The game's progression through levels is linear (for the most part), but the content of each area is procedurally generated, meaning it's different every time.  This includes the physical shape of the level as well as enemies and items.  It makes each run feel fairly unique.

3) Bullet-hell - This descriptor may be a bit misleading for some.  On the game's default easy difficulty setting, you'll be spammed with enemy bullets, sometimes in patterned formations, and in large quantities in the later levels.  But it's not nearly as much as a classic Bullet Hell" shmup like the TouHou games
date: so it may give a bad first impression to bullet-hell enthusiasts.  HOWEVER: If you want a higher difficulty you will quickly unlock "Planar Altars" which start showing up in the early areas
recommended:
and allow you to crank up the difficulty via the game's "Desecration" level.  This shows promise in satisfying more hardcore gamers.

What else is cool about Deathstate?  Here's some fun things that can keep you playing:
Collectible monster organs that you stuff into your body and make it more powerful
Artifacts and books that orbit around your character with active & passive abilities to
voteText: shoot more projectiles like magic missiles
votesHelpful:
fireballs...
A bunch of characters with different abilities and passive traits
^ You unlock more of the above nearly every time you play!
Shops where you can buy items or gamble your money away
GIANT chests!
An awesome aesthetic of otherworldly awe
votesFunny: and eldritch horror in varying amounts
commentsCount:
and good music to accompany it.
All around smooth controls which can be remapped and also support Xbox & Steam controllers
And possible cons:
Some of the visual effects may be bothersome to people.  I forgot they were there myself
column16: but they can't be disabled.\nThe boss attack patterns can become predictable after a while\nThere's a few buggy things in the Library's menus
column17: but at the time of this review the devs said they are working on it.\nI think this game is well worth the money if you like roguelikes
column24: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A lot of replay value, innovative gameplay, amazing music, difficult as it can get, the lovecraftian atmosphere and the very nice developers behind it make this game a great choice.

This game is a bullet hell with permadeath, with single-stick shooter controls and based on runs.

What is single-stick shooter? You only move and the character shoots in auto. This is, in my opinion, better than the twin-stick-shooter system, because it reduces complexity (moving and aiming at the same time), and allows you to focus on movement. This does not mean the game is not hard, just watch someone play the new insanity mode or finish a desecration run.

If you like Binding of Isaac, I strongly recommend this game. Also for the fans of other bullet hells/rogue-likes, I recommend you give this game a chance.

reviewText:
Surprisingly large amount of content. I was initially pretty reluctant to get into the game at first due to the auto-fire thing that your character does but the difficulty does ramp up and you'll probably be thankfully that you don't need to pick and choose individual targets with your main attack while you're trying to dodge a thousand evil glowsticks from every direction.

Good variety of items and enemies and with Lovecraft references galore.

If you're a fan of bullet hells, this game may or may not be your cup of tea. It's not as difficult as Mushihimesama but due to the nature of randomly generated levels and enemy placement, you don't get to memorize patterns.

If you're into rogue-lites then I'd definitely say give this game a shot.

reviewText:
I'm only a few hours in, and have lots more to do, but so far I'm pleased with this purchase.  I inevitably get frustrated somewhere around my fifth or sixth death, utter a loud expletive, and take a break. However, I keep coming back whenever there's a temporary lull in my day. Judging by the extensive list of items and features I have yet to unlock, I have a long way to go.

The controls are responsive and surprisingly simplistic. The etheric 'bullets' your character fires aren't aimed manually, but are instead fired automatically at the nearest enemies, making it your responsibility to put your astral explorer in the right place at the right time. The many swarms of weaker, projectile-less enemies can become a real problem, because they act as constant meat-shields to the more threatening enemies, prolonging every encounter and increasing your chances of losing precious hitpoints to your own incompetence.

Like most roguelike-likes,  the items you to pick up or don't pick up can make or break your run through the game, but you aren't entirely at the mercy of the Random Number Generator. Success always feels possible, if difficult, thanks to the bullet hell elements and the dodging mechanic. The many, many projectiles in the lower levels can be phased through or dodged by the directional arrow keys if you are fast enough, giving the game a high skill ceiling.

In short, the game is easy to learn and hard to master, and I give it extra points for the cool setting. I am very much enjoying this punishing fever dream of a game.
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
What a blast!  Easy to jump into, hard to shut off.  The concept is a deceptively simple one that has been around since the early arcade classics - avoid the bullets, kill the enemies.  The kicker here is the large selection of items and power ups that become available as you blast through 'runs'.

I'm constantly finding cool new pieces which augment my abilities and tweak my build on the fly.  A serious gamer could probably rip through the level content in a weekend, but the constant stream of unlocks and characters ensures anyone has a solid reason to revisit it for a quick fix.

This one will be on my 'active play' list for quite a long time!  A++++ Definitely recommend!

reviewText:
While this game might look like Nuclear Throne, the mechanics underneath these visuals feel more like The Binding of Isaac.

For example:
* Each level is procedurally generated
* Each floor" has a boss
* You move deeper into the game and it gets much much harder
* As you progress you unlock more characters
* There are 140+ weapons/items to unlock
* Tons of passive and active items
* There are item/weapon shops
* There are lots of little different active events that you can encounter

I realize some of these things are also in Nuclear Throne but all of these games are quite similar in some aspects.

TL;DR:
* Nuclear throne doesn't have the amount of unlocks/progression that Dead State has.
* The Binding of Isaac doesn't have the bullet hell that Dead State has
* This game is worth picking up IMO if you like Rogue-lites"
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this game in a pre-release version, and now since its release. It's got tons of personality - great artwork, synth music, psychedelic visual effects - it's sort of like Stuart Gordon's FROM BEYOND movie as a Saturday morning kids' cartoon, mixed with a 16-bit dungeon crawl, re-animated as a roguelite bullet hell shooter.

It's instantly gratifying with pick-up-and-play arcade style action, but with some item collecting and tons of unlockables to keep you going. It's weird, Lovecraftian, funny, and addicting. My only complaint is that death sets you all the way back to Layer 1, and the game can get repetitive if you have to progress through the same few levels over and over again just to get back to where you died. This design choice does limit your moves - you're less likely to be daring and take a risk if you know the last twenty minutes of your game might be wiped out because you got cornered.

Overall, I've very excited to see how this game continues to shape up as the developer adds new content and works out the kinks. I'll be spending plenty of time with it.

reviewText:
I've only scratched the surface, but I'm already loving this game. The aesthetic of the graphics and sfx/music is really unique and the single stick shooter style gameplay is surprisingly complex. Plus, the items and organs add so much to every build! The combination of unlocks and permadeath is working really well so far: All of your character's stats and items are reset when you die, but progress you make unlocks the possibility of new items spawning. It keeps making me want to play another run to try to find the latest eyeball or heart I've unlocked.

Also, the single stick style of the game lends itself surprisingly well to the Steam Controller. I'm loving playing it on the couch in the living room, the art looks amazing on a big TV!

reviewText:
A non-biased quick look @ the game:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0v020Z_r5y4

I have over 1,000 games in my Steam library, this game is now one of my all-time favourites. Deathstate is a roguelike, bullet hell, single stick shooter set in a bizarre world of dimensional exploration for pc and mac. You play as a number of unique characters trying to discover the fate of Professor Elinberg who opened a portal to the void. Great and terrible mysteries and even greater treasures await if you are bold or foolhardy enough to go beyond the beyond.

The Bizarre World of Deathstate
In Deathstate, you are a traveller of the outer realms. You have discovered the secrets of deep astral projection by entering into a fully death-like meditative state. While in your Deathstate, you can go beyond the beyond to realms previously only imagined by those enlightened or mad enough to dwell upon them. Tread lightly though, for these far planes of demi-existence that you choose to explore are extremely hostile to mortal souls. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
i'm very bad at dodging bullets and haven't played that many bullets hells but this game is really fun.

the colors is very vibrant while sometimes distracted me from seeing the bullets still gives it a very cool feels.
there are many items and it's pretty easy to figure out a sort of build that you want to run with once you start getting many items. there aren't that many slots so you can't end up with a million bullets shooting out of you but you can end up with items comboing each other. i ended up with a flame build that helped me burn my way to the end of the game but i still want to go back and pass it with other characters and see what else there is to unlock.

really fun game highly recomend it if you want a challenge!

reviewText: Great, great game. I've put this game on the backburner for as long as I could because I was not sure if it would fit my 'wants' when it comes to these types of games. I read a bunch of negative reviews about how you could only control your movement, as well as the ability to dodge/evade enemy projectiles. That sort of gave me a very doubtful view on the whole set-up of the game. I looked up a couple of let's plays by a few youtubers who have touched upon the game very lightly, but those didn't really help either. So I finally gave in and bought the game, and I can proudly say that I am very pleased with the purchase! The game is challenging, but not to the point where it's unforgiving. It provides the player with room for improvements and fair play, whereas a bunch of other rogue-like titles present you with insta-death followed by a steep learning curve. Definitely worth the pick-up, and absolutely hits the sweet spot when it comes to bullet hell.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Fun little roguelite bullet hell shooter. You can tell the developer is a fan of HP Lovecraft with the squid monsters and the hub of your adventuring being Miskatonic University.   It helps that it's only one stick and you auto shoot the closest mob because it makes this little gem a brain dead shooter.  Something to play while you wait to go to work or something I would imagine.  The graphics are very retro while also having some 3D here and there.

My only complaint is the lackluster music and sound effects.  But it is supposed to be SNES retro so I think that's what the dev's were going for.

Nevertheless, it is a hard as nails roguelite type game with upgrades so you will get alot of gameplay out of Deathstate.  Definately buy if you're a fan of simplistic roguelike type games.

reviewText: Fall into a dark hole and eradicate all that stands between you and... beyond. Be well. Be better. Be the best. Go past even that and become something so much less than human. SO much less, and SO much greater.\n\n(deathstate is a fantastic single-stick shooter that controls perfectly well on keyboard to boot. the aesthetic is great and the mechanics are tight. it is tough as nails, but stick with it and enjoy.)

reviewText: I bought this on a whim because of the Xmas sale, and was simply blown away. Deathstate does an amazing job of fusing a wonderful, thrilling 8-bit dangerfest with rich Lovecraftian story and flavor. I keep playing this over and over; unlocking more eldritch artifacts, kooky characters, fighting more bizarre and creepy enemies. Bottom line is, I've died a lot... and I've enjoyed every minute of it. Unlocking new levels and alternate bosses keeps the content very fresh, and I've been shocked by what I've found each time I've jumped through that portal. The developers of the game also seem to be adding more and more content all the time.\n\nIn closing, get this game, and join me in Deathstate bliss. 10/10

reviewText:
Check out my Quick Look of the game!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8SUdWC8x2ys

Deathstate is a new game developed and published by Workinman Interactive. The main draw with Deathstate is the atmosphere and creature design. You can tell that a lot of love was put into nailing the Lovecraftian aesthetic they have created. The gameplay is also tight and challenging especially into the later levels. It is  also a more than competent roguelike with many unlockable characters, weapons, items etc. I really enjoyed my time with the game because I have an affinity for Lovecraft and roguelikes. Having said that I don't know if there is enough here to convert anyone who is not already a fan of either genre. Overall, I would say if you have any interest in Lovecraft or roguelikes this game is definitely worth a purchase.

reviewText: Great roguelike game with good art style,smooth gameplay,nice music (it might seem repetitive at first but it complements the level really nice) and great level design.On the downside,i don't like how far bullets that enemies shoot travel/live (sometimes you might finish a pack of enemies,backtrack and dodge their bullets that are still flying) and some design features in levels that are not clearly(visually) marked as impassible (i died a couple of times because i got stuck on some corner of a wall,small gap in the floor or weird bump).All in all,a great game that is still being developed although it has been launched.A lot of content for just 15€ so i fully recommend this one

reviewText: A fascinating Cthulhoid action roguelike. Deathstate can most easily be compared to Binding of Isaac, only with Mythos monsters instead of weird body horror.\n\nGameplay: They call it a single-stick shooter"
date: as opposed to a "twin-stick shooter". What this means is that you move your character
recommended: and your character automatically fires at the closest target. At this point
hoursPlayed: some of you are probably saying "Whaaaat?"—let me assure you
voteText: though
helpfulPercent: that this is both fun and challenging. The way I play
votesHelpful: I have my left hand on WASD and my right on the arrow keys; the arrow keys activate a "dash" that lets you "phase through" bullets. Even though I'm not actively controlling where I shoot
votesTotal: I'm still making decisions every moment—What target should I move close to now? How close do I have to get so it's in range? Can I figure out its pattern and predict where I have to be next? Would it help if I dashed through this bullet
votesFunny: or would that put me in the path of something else? Can I run over there to the health item without running into bullets? Should I activate my character skill or my item skill
commentsCount: or should I save the MP/cooldown for when I really need it? Where should I go next in this level so as to find the exit before time runs out?\n\nOnce you get to the higher levels
column16: it starts feeling more like Touhou than anything else
column17: as you carefully maneuver through bullet patterns. (After all
column19: don't you just hold down the fire button all the time?) You also accumulate various items (this is where the "roguelike" aspect comes in). The items modify your damage
column22: and some give you skills that can be activated. You can only carry one grimoire
column24: and they float around you; when you find a new grimoire
column26: you have to consider which is best for your current build. There are other weird and interestingly gruesome items like eyes and spleens
column27: but you can collect as many of those as you like. Incidentally
column28: the levels are organized into worlds
column29: but randomly generated; each type feels different from the others
column30: and within a world each level is slightly different
column31: with a different combination of monsters for example—different monsters require very different tactics to take on.\n\nWhile I
column33: was never that good at Binding of Isaac
column34: I found myself able to get to the end of Deathstate with only a week or so of play. Of course
column35: that's hardly the "end" of the game; I can play with more unlocked characters
column36: I can use the "desecration portals" to increase the difficulty level...I have no doubt I could play this game for months
column37: if not years. Speaking of unlocks
column39: which is a good thing; even if you die
column40: very often you unlock something new to appear during play
column42: but very good. There are all sorts of crazy monsters. Some are admittedly "generic"
column43: like skeletons or liches. Some of them are obviously based on things from Cthulhu Mythos stories
column45: Gugs and Elder Things. Some are actually versions of the weirder Dungeons & Dragons monsters
column47: Beholders or Grells (here "Hawkminds"). And some of the monsters are original
column48: like the Molten Faces. As long as you don't hate pixel artwork—and you aren't grossed out by disembodied organs
column49: or by flesh melting off monsters when they die—I think you'll be impressed with the graphics.\n\nSpeaking of graphics
column50: I should mention the "scanline" effect. It's very well done; when you switch levels
column51: it almost feels like your monitor is turning on and off (it's just a graphical effect though). There's also a "brightness" effect; when you get a health item
column52: the screen glows with saturated colors for an instant. And when you get down to very low health
column53: everything looks gray and washed-out. Also
column54: when time runs out in a level
column56: or sometimes phantoms appear all over the screen. And certain monsters can actually increase the scanlines or brightness
column57: making it seem like when you get close to them
column58: the entire game is being affected. These graphical touches act as cues for events in the game...and they also just appear bizarre and fascinating. (By the way
column59: I think the scanline effects can be turned off in the options.)\n\nMusic and Sound: Excellent. Well
column60: it's sort of a vaguely chiptune-esque feel; I understand the composers (well
column61: everyone involved) were inspired by Genesis games; imagine Ecco the Dolphin meeting Cthulhu. Also
column62: Carcassus will make you think of DOOM (in many ways). Honestly
column63: I liked the music so much I bought the soundtrack DLC
column64: and I NEVER do that. As for sound
column65: there are lots of nice cues; you can tell when a health item drops somewhere in view
column66: and you can tell that it's different from a gold drop. Acquiring health produces a nice "gulp". When you meet an elite monster
column67: it announces itself with diabolical laughter—to say nothing of the demonic cackle that heralds a boss.\n\nStory: The story is
column69: vague: You have followed a Professor into a dimension filled with monsters
column70: and now you have to defeat him and/or escape. The
column73: is quite good; what I'm referring to
column75: is the descriptions of monsters and items
column76: tiny bits of Lovecraftian prose you can read once you've encountered/unlocked the thing in question. Also
column78: various characters will pop up and say random things. This ranges from the Professor threatening you
column79: to skeletons making references to old games
column80:
to the undead merchant saying truly bizarre things ("A brain is a terrible thing to only have one of"). The point I'm trying to make is that the story and writing don't have a big role—nor do they need to—but they're good for what they are.

IN SUMMARY: I'm coming back to it and playing it again and again. Highly recommended.
"

reviewText: Deathstate is a pick-up and play" style bullet-hell dodge-shooter.  Playthroughs are typically 15 to 30 minutes long and beyond WASD for movement the other main keys are "F" to examine and the arrow keys to dodge (all keys can be re-bound to whatever you like).  The keys needed to use potions and other items are helpfully overlaid on the on-screen display you see while you play.\n\nShould you buy Deathstate?  Well
date: if you are a casual gamer like myself who likes to occasionally unwind playing simple yet fun RPG-styled games then the answer is "yes!"  Deathstate features a mix of science-fiction / horror-style chiptune music mixed with some very fun heavy metal for one of the mini-boss fights you can choose on every playthrough.  The metal track (called "Desecrate") on the Original Sound Track (OST) is thrilling.  I would compare it to the game version of an all-out table-and-chair throwing bare-knuckle brawl with Satan himself
recommended: set against the background of the cosmos.  Good stuff.\n\nWhile I don't see myself putting hundreds of hours into Deathstate the game is
voteText: fantastic.  It is a pick-up and play sci-fi horror-style RPG game with very simple game mechanics and challenging enemies and bosses.  I have heard some people find the on-screen overlay disorienting during long play throughs.  I haven't and I am prone to motion sickness.  I recommend picking up this game on sale if you enjoy this style of game."

reviewText:
Do you want a game which can fill up your time with good content and challenge? Do you like to mix element from danmaku (bullet curtain) and rogue-like? Then you have your game : Deathstate.

This review has been made after clearing the full game at version 1.13, which means 100% achievement and the hardest possible run.


For which player ?Thanks to a scaled difficulty the game can be played by both novice to danmaku and experts. However, as it is now this can has some flashy effect that may pose a problem for color-blind people along with those having photo-sensibility.

Pros :    The game is alive : you can post on the forum and the developer is present to answer and give insight on the game and its future, which is a strong point as bug fixing is ensured by the presence of the developer.
MusicThe music is good and sounds effects are carefully used. Thank to this mix, you can hear what is happening around you, which is pretty valuable for hardest difficulty.
Art : Simple and effective pixel art in the Lovecraft world. Even if it is not extremely original"
recommended:
the game has its own style and you will remember it.
A good choice of characters : As for now there are 10 playable characters and 3 in-run transformation that will modify the gameplay from a little to a lot. This is good as you can have some affinity with a certain type of gameplay (dodging or heavy DPS) which is present in the characters.
Privacy : It is the first game which ASKED me if I wanted my data collected for improving the game anonymously. Just for having the game asking my consent it is a great pro in this market where some developer have no concern for players' privacy.
Cons :    Color effects : It is how the game has been programmed and it serves in its difficulty by adding coloration effect (color inversion
voteText: increased gamma) making difficult to see where are the bullet on the screen. However
helpfulPercent: I believe this is a con for people who cannot stand such effect
votesHelpful: may it be for personnal taste or medical reason.\nHeavy RNG : As for now
votesTotal: hardest difficulty are way too much RNG dependent. There are build where you simply cannot go on
votesFunny: which lead to reset fest.\nNo lore : The last con I would add is the scenario and the lore. There is little to no scenario in this game. You are trapped in a simulation like
commentsCount: you kill monster and that's pretty all. Therefore you play the game for the gameplay and not for unfolding the scenario.\nOverall? I recommend to buy the game at full price for people who do love danmaku and rogue-like. If you are not a big player of danmaku or rogue-like you can buy it either full price or on small sales. If you hate one of those style or are waiting for a Lovecraft like story

reviewText:
Deathstate is a fun game. There's not much doubting that. It's also very frustrating. Also no doubting that.
The mechanics are easy to master, and with the variety of mostly useless equipment that you can pick up, most runs will be quite different than each other, and this is a good thing. The graphical style is pleasing, and the colors are quite nice, even though sometimes enemy bullets seem to blend in with everything else. The music is very good, and is probably the first soundtrack I've heard in a while that had a true retro feel to it.
Bullet Hell, Rougelike. Painful heaven.
However, I think that there are two poor decisions made with it.
If you want to make a difficult skill based game, that's fine. Dark Souls is fairly difficult with mechanics that can be mastered, Touhou is a series another good example of that. However, I feel that even will skill, the reason this game will still be difficult is not because it requires luck, but rather because of the visual filter that frequently brightens and can sometimes pulsate, making bullets impossible to see. Or, at least, very difficult to see. I can't judge if this was an intentional decision to increase difficulty, or if it was simply a stylistic choice. It /feels/ like a cheap way to increase difficulty, and I don't like that one bit.
The second, and probably more minor and definitely weighing on my lack of knowledge, is that most of the organs in the game seem to provide minimal benefit if any at all. This could change later in the game, perhaps the slight pushes in either direction will affect the outcome of a run, and I can't currently say if that's true or not.
If I were to give this game an honest rating, I'd give it 6.5/10. It's decent and fun, and I will definitely be playing every other day, but I will always hold a small resentment for it in my heart for the cheap deaths it often presents me with.

reviewText:
Deathstate is a game that I wanted to like. The idea of simplifying 2D shooters to a movement only based scheme is novel. It allows the player to focus on dodging and placement. This would be great if everything built around it wasn't so faulty.

The music in the game ranges anywhere from tolerable to aural punishment. The Maze of Ix has undoubtledy the worst track I've heard in a game in years. The art style is quite nice, even though various enemies are recycled through areas. Half of the enemies are barely animated, though. Visual design choices also get in the way of the gameplay. One of the zones cycles through colors, and some of those are almost the same hue as the bullets. Using or picking up healing items accompanies with a blinding flash that blocks out vision of projectiles. The clutter and aesthetic bits strewn about the levels make it hard to tell what can be walked over and what can't. Factor in that characters get stuck on corners like they're coated with rubber cement, and you have chunks of life lost to bad movement.

Aside from characters getting stuck, the core mechanics of the game don't work as well as they should. Runs are almost entirely determined by the quality of items picked up. Some items are good, most are relatively unimpactful, and some are outright bad. Why have an item that increases damage but slows rate of fire to once a second when the player is going to be surrounded by enemies? The later levels are swarmed by high health enemies that fill the screen with bullets. That could be forgiven if the player wasn't also on a timer to get through each stage. If they items picked up during the run were below par, then winning is almost surely out of the question. Money even feels like a wasted resource because shops are rare and usually are either a straight up gamble or just have consumables, which may or may not be bad.

I don't recommend the game in its current state, and I don't expect it will improve drastically enough for me to change my mind. If you are considering this game, I strongly urge you to look at Nuclear Throne instead. Although much harder, Nuclear Throne is well worth your time and money.
(Sidenote: At the time of writing, many items in the game outright do not work if you use an XBox One controller. Expect to use your keyboard or another controller until this is patched.)

reviewText:
Gameplay: 7/10
Game has alot of fun moments but sometimes i find myself running around spamming the dodge move while my character auto fires. i think thats a rather boring choice, i was expecting a more free shooting motion not walk within this distance to a enemy and you're character will fire. by all means it slowed me down and made me less hypered up for the bloody crazy time i'd have in a eldritch horror filled nightmare"

Story: 10/10
Its about as good as you'd expect from the trailer

Conclusion:
I do not suggest this game because it is entirely bad. but its got many awkward flaws with it that make it needlessly dull and boring since in my experience i can't fire on my own and it doesn't leave make me very excited. and when you beat a boss the game checks in with you with the form of "here! have a new item you'll see a few hundred times...also having fun yet?" to which i say no. its not like the binding of isaac where i can find a whole cache of weapons over each playthrough and i don't want to
date: but it does help to make the boring auto fire mode a bit forgiveable. though the game has its charm i just can't personally see this game being entertaining or much fun- though it is a challenge! the auto fire shoots at walls sometimes and will lead you to your death because you CAN'T fire the enemy nearest to you. it just shoots at one it pre-selects important."

reviewText:
I wrote out a huge review entailing why I had to give it a no, but Steam ♥♥♥♥ed up as per usual so screw it. It's gonna get downvoted anyway. TL;DR Items are mostly negative, characters are kinda bland, most pick-ups are extremely high risk with little to no reward, annoying mechanics, the weapons suck, the trinkets are basically repeats of charcter abilities, that are all meh under level 3, etc, etc. It saved the last chunk of my review so, there.

Anyway, if you're into stupid hard bullet-hell, Cthulhu stuff with glowing ♥♥♥♥ that gives you a headache, then by all means go for it. I don't think I've ever had a game really give me a headache this bad before. I don't even know what the damn rune does or the random sliding across the map. It's an interesting game, I'm 100% sure people will downvote this into oblivion, but I just can't hit yes.

I'm not gonna pretend like I'm amazing at Rogue-Likes, or anything like that, but the difficulty+timer is just irritating as hell. When I play I don't feel like I'm learning or getting better, if anything I feel like I'm just getting lucky. After 7.4 hours, I still don't feel I've learned anything or improved at all outside of being better at dodging. I don't like that feeling, I don't like what that entails. If I can't really improve, and I don't want to continue playing then that's kinda the nail in the coffin for me.

If the devs crank the difficulty right up

reviewText: I like the core mechanic of this game, where I just move and dodge while my player automatically shoots. There are some nice graphics and sound. But this is the lazy kind of roguelike -- the levels are super random feeling and rarely lend themselves to interesting interactions. There are a million items, but they are not that interesting because they all basically just affect my stats and don't really change how I play. I beat it but it didn't hold my interest enough to keep studying or play through on harder difficulties, or recommend to you.\n\nGames to play instead: Spelunky, Crypt of the Necrodancer, Binding of Isaac: Afterbirth
